He reads what looks to be the Arabic version of People magazine. 180

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, Jack... we're on our own. We?? 53.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Help me to get that other chip back. Jack looks miserable.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This is really bad timing. I mean, I just got a few extra days vacation, and on Monday I'm supposed to leave on a cruise... 181

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) Gee, Jack... how thoughtless of me. (then, in a normal tone of voice) Look: You heard the guy. I got twenty hours of air left. I wouldn't worry about missing your cruise. 182

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You know... that isn't much time.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (again; very sarcastic) Gosh, you're right! Why didn't I think of that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I mean, what happens if we fail? What happens if we don't get this chip back and your air supply runs out? What happens then?!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Then you've got a miniaturized submersible pod floating around your insides with a tiny, little human skeleton at the helm.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (revolted) Aaagghh!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Not a pretty thought, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 54. Jack begins to bang his head against the steering wheel. 183

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: is also being rocked back and forth by Jack's head moveme And Tuck's head is SLAMMED against the console a few time as well. 184

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack enters, glances at the exploded TV, then heads towar the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I need some aspirin. My head is killing me. Maybe it's my allergies. 185

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: rubs his own battered forehead.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Maybe it's from banging it against the steering wheel. 186

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: picks up the aspirin bottle from the counter and fills a glass with water when a KNOCK is heard at the door.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: The door.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Be careful... Jack opens the door to find a MESSENGER standing there.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Mr. Jack Putter?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: (hands him an envelope) From World Tour Travel. Jack looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Cruise tickets, I think. (hands him a clipboard) Sign on number twelve. (as Jack signs) Mind if I use your phone? Gotta call my dispatcher.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (returning clipboard) Oh, well... okay. Sure. The Messenger comes in, sees the exploded TV.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Shot out your TV, huh, man? Just like Elvis. Jack doesn't respond. He just points out the phone. Messenger picks it up and dials. The

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Lucky man. Goin' on a cruise. What about your roommate?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Roommate?

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Thought I heard you talkin' to somebody as I came to the door. No. 187

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I live here alone.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Don't trust him! He's not a messenger! 188

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: turns his back on the messenger.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I got a gut reaction! Call it survival instinct. Get out now. Jack turns back toward the Messenger who is talking into the phone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 56.

dialogues.speaker: MESSENGER
dialogues.text: Okay. I made the drop. Everything's cool. The Messenger hangs up the phone -- sees that Jack is looking at him strangely. Jack glances at the door. The Messenger grows suspicious. Jack makes a dash for the door. gun and leaps after him. The Messenger draws a But the throw rug slides out from beneath the Messenger's feet and the Messenger goes flying! Jack swings open the door -- it CONNECTS with the Messeng the floor, the gun still clutched in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Run! 189

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack runs from the apartment into the courtyard. what he sees: 190

dialogues.speaker: THREE MEN IN DARK BUSINESS SUITS
dialogues.text: entering the courtyard. 191 This is One of the men is Igoe.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ducks behind a palm tree, out of sight. Igoe and his two Henchmen pass by, heading for Jack's apartment. When safe, Jack runs off. 192

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack runs into the parking area, but stops short. Igoe's Henchmen is standing guard over his VW. One of Jack steps back into the shadow of a garbage dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: They're watching my car.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Go to a pay phone. Call a cab.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Where am I going? How am I gonna pay for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 57.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You're going to my place. You can pay the cabbie when you get there... my treat. 193

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks around.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nice place. (under his breath) What a dump.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I heard that... and you're right. (beat) I could use a drink, Jack. Bet you could, too.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't drink.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Well, I do. See if there's a bottle of Cutty under the sofa cushion, would ya? Jack makes a face, but takes a look.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: The other cushion. No!

dialogues.speaker: ON TUCK'S VIDEO
dialogues.text: We see Jack's hands flip over the cushion and find the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Got it. 195

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: is licking his lips.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Okay! Here's what you do: Take a nice big tug on that baby and I'll see what I can catch on the way down.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 58.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Let me worry about that. 196

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Pod's articulating arms extends out from the Pod's body with a soft, mechanical WHIRRING sound. Clutched in the arm's claw is Tuck's empty flask. 197

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuck looks out the viewing dome to make sure arm and flask are properly in place.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Okay, Jack -- down the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm not much of a drinker. C'mon!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Let 'er rip! Then: A TIDAL WAVE of AMBER LIQUID SPLASHES down from above and CRASHES against the Pod. The Pod rolls over and over in the THUNDERING alcohol current. Finally it comes to rest in some dark, vestibular channel of Jack's digestive system. Tuck presses a few buttons and the articulating arm begins to retract into the Pod. Claw and flask slide into the Pod through and air-lock opening.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Come on, lucky flask! Tuck eagerly grabs the flask and sloshes it around under his nose. His expression sours.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Smells a little strange. (peeks at it) Looks a shade green. (shrugs it off) Oh, well. Probably just some harmless biochemical waste material... Hmmm. Then a drop splashes out onto his jumpsuit, HISSING and burning a small hole in the fabric.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: ... mixed with a bit of stomach acid. (pause) What the hell! (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 59.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rot-gut whiskey's better than none at all. Cheers! He throws back a drink. His eyes fill with tears and he GASPS for air. He begins to pound his fists against the console and he makes a full spin in his swivel chair.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (wiping his mouth with his sleeve) Wow! That's strong enough to grow hair on a snake! Tuck takes another belt. 198

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: also seems pleased by what has just passed his lips. He looks at the bottle's label, shrugs his shoulders, and takes another drink. 199

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: really feels relaxed. He rummages around and eventually finds what he's looking for: An audio cassette. 200

dialogues.speaker: CASSETTE
dialogues.text: Sam Cooke's Greatest Hits. 201

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: inserts the tape into a player and kicks back.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Nuthin' like a little Cutty and Sam Cooke to chase away the miseries of the day. 202

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Sedan carrying Igoe and his Henchmen ROARS by. 203

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igoe sits in the back seat wearing an expression of stony resolution. The car presses on relentlessly. 204

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rocking to the music of Sam Cooke's "TWISTIN' THE NIGHT AWAY." Tuck leans back, flask in hand, foot tapping against the console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 60.

dialogues.speaker: SAM COOKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (singing) Here's a man in evenin' clothes, how he got here, I don't know. But, man, you ought to see him go... Twistin' the night away! 205

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: is lip synching to the song and twisting his heart out. He's infused with the spirit of the music... and perhaps with the spirit of the Cutty as well.

dialogues.speaker: SAM COOKE'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (singing) Lean up! Lean back! Twistin' the night away! 206

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Jack!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (shouting over the music) Hey, Jack! (finally turns the music low) Jack!

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What?...

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Go look in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Because I just realized I don't know what you look like. 207

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: turns, looks for a mirror. staggers over to it. 208 Sees one on the wall. He

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: can tell by looking into his monitor that Jack is weaving from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Hey, you're not drunk, are you? No.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Just a little dizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 61.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (amused) Ha! And after only one stinking drink! 209

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: approaches the mirror. He looks at the Cutty bottle in his hand. It's almost half empty.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: More than one drink, I think... (looks into mirror) ... How's this? 210

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: sees in his monitor Jack's face as it is reflected in the mirror. But Jack is way too close, creating a distorted fish-eye look. Too close.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Back up. Back up. Jack does.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: That's better... For a moment Tuck just looks at the face of the man whose body he inhabits. Then, he turns OFF the MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Jack... I guess you realize some very serious bad guys are after you because of me. So if you want to bail out, I understand. Just sneeze me into a Kleenex or something and hand it over to them. 211

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: stares into the mirror with a besotted expression.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Didn't you just save my life?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You warned me about that phony messenger. Well, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I guess I did, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 62.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: -- So just shut up about the Kleenex! 212

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: realizes that Jack, in his own way, is saying he won't quit. Tuck is moved.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Jack. 213

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: turns away from the mirror, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: But let's face it... We need help. Can you drive? Is your head clear?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well... uh...

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Slap yourself in the face.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Huh? In the face. Wack!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Slap yourself. Jack does.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Harder. Wack! Jack does it harder.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Again. Wack! Jack does it again.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How's that feel?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: One more time! Wack! Jack does it one more time. Okay!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How's that feel now?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It feels good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 Okay! 214 63.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let's roll!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear it before we see it. The FULL-THROATED ROAR of its twelve cylinder, 4.4. liter engine. The garage door swings up revealing a: 215

dialogues.speaker: FIRE-ENGINE RED 1969 FERRARI DAYTONA
dialogues.text: One of the most awesome road machines ever produced. Jack is behind the wheel. He just touches the gas pedal and the car rockets out of the garage. 216

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack SQUEALS around the hair-pin curves leading away from Tuck's hillside house.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're sober!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Igoe's black sedan barrels around the bend towards them. The Ferrari crosses the center line. Jack SCREAMS and yanks on the wheel. The Black Sedan skids off the road and onto the shoulder in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'm sober now! 217

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was them! around!

dialogues.speaker: IGOE
dialogues.text: Turn around! Turn But the sedan is stalled, and now the engine fails to turn over. It GROANS uncooperatively.

dialogues.speaker: IGOE
dialogues.text: I hate this black sedan! I want a new black sedan! I want a Mercedes-Benz 500 SEL!!

dialogues.speaker: HENCHMAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Igoe. Then: the engine fires up -- SPUTTERS -- and the car lurches into gear. 218

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ferrari barrels along. Jack clutches the steering whe with both hands -- as if the car might speed out from und him.  INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 219 63A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuck has his eyes glued to the monitor which displays Jack's POV of the freeway, etc.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (nervously) Watch out for that truck up ahead. Change lanes -- get in the fast lane. Wait -- not now. Okay -now. Watch your tachometer. shift into fifth! Easy on the clutch. Always shift at 4500 RPMs. Keep an eye on the temperature gauge... Boy!

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Talk about back seat drivers!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: This car's a classic! It's the only thing I own that's worth a shit! 220 221

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe you should tell me where I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Downtown. We're gonna look up a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duane Florney is at his desk talking with the CITY EDITOR Lydia practically flies by.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I'm off, Duane!

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Hey, Lydia! Wait a minute. are you going? Where

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Airport.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: What about this Vector-Scope story!?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I'm playing a hunch, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: This could be big, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Hey -- who do you two think you are, anyway? Redford and Newman?  Revised 11/8/85 64. Lydia does a double take.

dialogues.speaker: DUANE
dialogues.text: (to Editor) I think you mean Woodward and Bernstein, chief. Lydia disappears out the door. 222

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia emerges from the Newspaper Building and heads for her car parked at the curb. At the same moment, Jack and Tuck in the red Ferrari come down the street. 223

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: That's her!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Where??

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I saw her out of the corner of your eye. Jack looks around.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Getting into her car! Hurry! She'll get away. Honk your horn! Jack hits the HORN. It has a very distinctive sound. Lydia turns and looks in Jack's direction. 224

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Sunlight glistens off her copper-colored hair. looks beautiful. 225 She

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Immediately smitten. 226

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia marches up to the parked Ferrari.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Tuck) Here she comes. Lydia arrives at the car. Jack opens his mouth to speak, but doesn't get a chance:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 65.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I know this car. This car belongs to Tuck Pendelton! What are you doing with Tuck Pendelton's car!? Tuck would sooner trust somebody with his life than with his Ferrari. How'd you get this car? Who are you, anyway? Does Tuck know you have this car!? 227

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (out of frustration) Lydia, shut up and listen!! 228

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (blurts it out automatically) Lydia, shut up and listen!! Lydia looks shocked. 229 Jack wants to eat his words.

dialogues.speaker: THE BLACK SEDAN
dialogues.text: pulls up to the curb across the street from where Jack an Lydia are talking. Igoe and his Henchmen pile out. One Henchman slams the door on Igoe's hand. Igoe doesn't even flinch. He just looks down at his hand. All five fingers are caught in the tightly closed door. The guilty Henchman looks worried for his own safety, but Igoe calmly opens the door and pulls his hand free. 230

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: catches sight of Igoe and the Henchmen who are prevented from crossing the street by heavy traffic.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Oh, no -- it's them! Lydia looks up with a quizzical expression.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hop in! Lydia hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hop in! Tuck's in trouble! needs your help! He Lydia takes a chance. She jumps in beside Jack and the FERRARI SQUEALS away from the curb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 231

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Atta girl, Lydia! 232

dialogues.speaker: IGOE
dialogues.text: signals his men back into the black sedan. 65A.  Revised 11/8/85 233 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ferrari only gets one block before it must stop at a light. Jack bangs his fist against the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Who are those men?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Very bad guys! Bad guys! The Black Sedan also comes to a stop -- about ten cars ba It's a long light and Jack is getting nervous. over his shoulder. 234 He glances

dialogues.speaker: IGOE AND HIS HENCHMEN
dialogues.text: decide to leave their sedan and rush Jack on foot. They r up the line of stopped vehicles and get within a car's le of the Ferrari when: Blink! The light turns green. The Ferrari SQUEALS through the intersection, burning rub Igoe and his Henchmen turn and run back toward the Black Igoe gets there first. He doesn't bother to wait for the others. He slides in behind the wheel and ZOOMS away. The Henchmen are left standing in the street. 235

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack glances into the rearview for glimpses of the Black

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I don't see 'em. I think we gave 'em the slip! 236

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Sedan is stalled in the middle of the intersect causing a major traffic jam. HORNS HONK madly. Igoe jumps from the car and SLAMS the door in anger. He then looks around, wrestles a bicycle away from an OLD CHINAMAN and pedals off in pursuit of Jack. 237

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia and Jack at one of the tables.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: ... you might say Tuck's been taken hostage.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Who has him?  INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 67.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's a little hard to explain. We need something called a 'PEM' to get him back. It's a microchip. It was taken from the Vector-Scope lab this morning.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Vector-Scope! Everything's comin' up Vector-Scope today. Have you gone to the police?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: There's no time for long explanations and police reports. As a matter of fact, we only have... 238

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: checks his air supply gauge.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Sixteen hours. 239

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sixteen hours.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Sixteen hours?! Can't we negotiate for more time?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not a chance. Jack begins to squirm uncomfortably in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I gotta pee real bad! Lydia looks aghast. Jack freaks.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can't believe I said that! 240

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igoe pedals up to the restaurant. He sees the parked Ferr and smiles to himself. He discards the bike and approache the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 241 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands before the urinal, relieving himself. restaurant CUSTOMER washes his hands at the sink.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me she was going to be so beautiful. The Customer at the sink glances over at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Absolutely. (beat) And I think we should tell her the truth, too. Another

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 69. Again, the Customer looks over in Jack's direction, sees him looking down into the urinal, talking softly.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who would believe it? (pause) Besides... it's humiliating being this small. There -- I've said it!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What's so bad about being small? The Customer now comes up behind Jack.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMER
dialogues.text: Play with it, pal, but don't talk to it. With that, the Customer exits the restroom. mortified. Jack looks

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Never mind. Jack flushes the urinal -- watches the water swirl down the drain.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You still there?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah... why?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Just checking. 242

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack emerges from the rest room and approaches the table. We see JACK'S POV as he moves toward Lydia. Lydia looks up -- then registers alarm. She rises from her chair and draws what appears to be a gun from her purse and takes aim -- seemingly at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Freeze! Restaurant patrons SCREAM and take cover under tables. Ja stands there, frozen in horror. Then he looks behind him sees:

dialogues.speaker: IGOE
dialogues.text: Who stops in his tracks and slowly raises his hands above his head. 244

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Igoe's face appears on his display monitor -- then the pi suddenly scrambles. All the instruments begin to go haywi Needles on gauges spin. Lights flash. Radio reception BUZ Tuck doesn't know which problem to attend to first. 245

dialogues.speaker: THE RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Lydia has the drop on Igoe.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: This is an electronic stun-gun. A non-lethal personal defense weapon deploying a charge of 5,000 volts. It will immobilize you for up to twenty minutes and, in all probability, render you unconscious as well. So, don't take one step closer. Igoe looks at the gun. on his face. An expression of abject terror

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: (to a waiter) Call the police! Igoe suddenly grabs Jack.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: No! She squeezes back on the trigger. A STUN DART shoots out the weapon. Igoe uses Jack as a shield and the dart hits 246

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S MARKET NAME TAG
dialogues.text: The dart penetrates the plastic name tag, melting it inst and releasing half its charge with a loud BUZZZZ! The other 2,500 volts enter Jack's body, and Jack goes li in Igoe's arms. 247

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: also feels the impact of the electrical charge. CRACKLING ribbons of electric current dance around the contours of Pod. Tuck is SLAMMED back into his seat as electricity courses through his limbs.  Revised 11/8/85 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pod's lights dim, then brighten once again. But Tuck left a shaken man. His hair sticks straight up in current Punker fashion, and his head glows from within like a jack-o'-lantern. Tuck's consciousness returns, when the Pod is suddenly turned upside down as... 248

dialogues.speaker: IGOE
dialogues.text: picks up Jack's limp body and tosses it over his shoulder like a sack of flour. Igoe runs from the restaurant amid an UPROAR of YELLING and SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Someone call the police!! As Igoe runs off, the FERRARI KEYS slip from Jack's pocke and fall to the floor. Lydia sees this and snatches them 249

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igoe runs down the alley with Jack over his shoulder. Jac begins to snap out of it. He can't imagine where he is or why he's being conveyed this way. (We also see that he, t sports an electrified Punk hairdo.) Igoe notices a DELIVERY TRUCK pulling away from a loading He's able to pop open the cargo doors and throw Jack insi But now the truck is driving away. Igoe runs alongside of It begins to pick up speed. Igoe keeps up with it, leaps a running board, throws open the cab door, yanks out the driver and takes his place behind the wheel. The truck THUNDERS down the alley at top speed. 250

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Is grateful to see his instruments come back on line. The is righted once again, its speed and direction under cont

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Jack! Jack! Are you all right? What happened? Seems like we experienced a massive power surge. No response from Jack. Tuck looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Hey, Jack... you there, babe? He glances at one of his gauges in alarm.  Revised 11/8/85 72.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: What's goin' on, Jack!? Your heart rate's slowin' way down!

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm f-f-f-f-f-fTUCK (relieved) Jack! You had me worried. Thought I'd lost you for a minute, kid. (beat) What happened? Where's Lydia? Where are we? (peers into his monitor) I can't see a thing. Why's it so dark?

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm f-f-f-f-f-f-fTUCK You're what?? Can't make you out, Jack. Message garbled. Try again.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm f-f-f-f-f-f-freezing!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: You're freezing?? 251

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Igoe behind the wheel. CAMERA PANS to the sign lettered on truck's side. It reads: BAY AREA FROZEN FOOD SUPPLY CO.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Jack! What's that loud tapping sound!? 252

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S TEETH
dialogues.text: CHATTERING loudly. (The tapping sound heard by Tuck.)

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL
dialogues.text: Jack huddled in the corner among the boxes of frozen food His entire body shaking beneath a thin layer of frost. Hi Punk hair spikes looking like inverted icicles. 253

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Frozen Food truck is parked. A LIMO rolls up beside i Henchmen rush to open the back door, and VICTOR SCRIMSHAW slides out. Scrimshaw's dress and demeanor suggest a man near limitless power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 254 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cargo doors are flung open. Sunlight pours in. Jack lifts his head to look, squinting against the light. He resembles some kind of friendly snow creature. Scrimshaw climbs into the truck. One of the Henchmen thou making him look even more formidable than before. Snowflakes cling to Jack's eyelashes as he looks up at the towering Scrimshaw. Scrimshaw looks down at Jack impassively, then calls off: Dr. Canker!

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Get in here! Dr. Margaret Canker sweeps out of the limo and is helped into the truck's cargo area by a Henchman. Scrimshaw indicates Jack. Canker whips out a stethoscope and checks Jack's chest.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: Early stage hypothermia.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: (mulls it over) Do we need him alive? Jack's eyes widen at this.

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: He should be alive. Oh, yes. Jack looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: (to Henchman) Bring a blanket!

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: I know how to warm him up... She begins to run her hand up the inside of Jack's leg. Jack's eyes widen again.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Knock it off, Margaret! a blanket. Here comes The Henchman clambers into the truck with an instantly produced blanket and drapes it over Jack's shoulders.  INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 74.

dialogues.speaker: HENCHMAN
dialogues.text: We're taking him to the lab now, Mr. Scrimshaw. Would you like ride in the limo?

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: No, no. Go on ahead. It's a short trip. I'm going to stay back here and keep an eye on him.

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: I'll stay with him.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Forget it, Margaret. Take the limo. Canker packs up her medical bag as if she didn't care. 255

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Henchman closes the truck's cargo doors, then jumps into the limo. The limo drives away. Then the truck begins to rumble off as well. 256

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrimshaw pulls up a box of frozen food and takes a seat next to Jack. He lights up a fat cigar and blows smoke into the air.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Nuclear weapons, Jack?... (beat) ... They mean nothing. Everybody's got 'em; nobody's got the balls to use 'em. Am I right? Jack shivers silently, not daring to say a word.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Space you say? (pause) Space is a flop. Didn't you know that? An endless junk yard of orbiting debris. (pause) Ahhhh... but miniaturization, Jack. That's the ticket. (beat) It's the edge everyone's been looking for. But who will have that edge, Jack? What country will control miniaturization? (pause) Frankly, I don't give a shit. I'm only in this for the money. And that's why we gotta get that little pod out from inside of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 75. Scrimshaw punctuates this remark with a finger jabbed forcefully into Jack's ribs. Jack looks worried. Scrimshaw settles back to enjoy his cigar. 257

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia zips along in the open-topped Ferrari. A truck trie to pass her. She casually glances up at its driver -- and recognizes Igoe behind the wheel. Lydia reacts. She lightens up on the gas, allowing the truck to pull ahead of her. 258

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: I have some bad news for us, Jack. Looks like we've fallen into the hands of the bandits. They're taking us to some lab, and I don't like the sound of that. 259

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: listens in silence. Huddled under the blanket, he has begun to warm up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Jack... glance around slowly so that I can get the lay of the land. 260

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boxes of frozen foods come into view. Then the hulking, f

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Go back, Jack! Go back. Go back to the doors. Jack's glance returns to the doors. We see that they are not properly closed. The latch is not in place. A crack of daylight shows through. 261

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: views the unlocked doors on his monitor.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Jack, this is it. The doors are unlocked. We can take them by surprise: Bust outta here before they know what hit 'em! (beat) Can you do it, Jack? Cough if you can do it. Tuck waits for the cough. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Okay, Jack. Listen to me. This is your moment. This is your turn to be the hero, Jack. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: 75A.
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 76.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Psyche yourself up. Look at the doors. (You gonna stack soup cans all your life, Jack?) See yourself leaping to your feet. (Gonna bag groceries until you die, Jack?) See yourself pushing open the doors! See yourself jumping from the truck! Can you see it, Jack!? Can you see it!? 262

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Sheds his blanket and jumps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I can see it!!

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Huh! Jack! No!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Wait until -- Jack charges toward the cargo doors and flings them open.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: -- the truck has stopped... Too late. The doors swing out. The highway flies by underneath at sixty miles per hour. Jack clings to one of the doors.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ohhhhhhhhhhh!!!... Jack holds on for dear life -- his feet kicking in midair several feet above the surface of the roadway. Scrimshaw tries to reach out and grab him. it's just too damned dangerous. He fails --

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: You stupid idiot! 263

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: shares Jack's POV of his precarious situation. can't look. He covers his eyes. 264 Tuck

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: sees events unfolding before her. now she speeds up. She has kept back, but

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: begins to POUND against the back wall to alert Igoe in the driver's cab.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Stop the truck! Stop the truck! 266

dialogues.speaker: IGOE
dialogues.text: has a radio turned up FULL VOLUME playing "Ride of the Valkyries." He can't hear Scrimshaw's pounding. We notice that Jack, swinging on the cargo door, is brief visible in the sideview mirror. Igoe glances into the mir but too late: Jack has already swung back out of sight. 267

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: sees that the door is swinging back toward the truck. He positions himself to grab hold of Jack. Jack sees what's coming. He puts out his foot and kicks off against Scrimshaw's chest.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Ooomph! Jack and the door swing back out over the highway, and Scrimshaw tumbles backwards into the boxes of frozen food 268

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: ZOOMS up behind the truck.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Jump in, Jack! Jump in! 269

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: looks down. Both vehicles are doing sixty and the door is swinging back and forth. Scrimshaw has gotten to his feet and is advancing unstead toward Jack.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Jump!

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Jump! Jack lets his feet drop down into the Ferrari, but contin to cling to the door with his hands.  Revised 11/8/85 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two vehicles begin to drift apart. Jack's hands are attached to one; his feet are attached to the other. It looks like he's being stretched. Lydia reaches out, grabs Jack's pant leg.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Let go! Let go!?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Are you crazy!! Lydia steers the Ferrari in closer to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Now let go! Jack lets go and falls backwards into the Ferrari's passenger seat. Lydia stomps on the gas pedal and ROARS off ahead of the truck. She sees a sign up ahead: S.F. INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT -Nex including the truck, and takes the exit. 270

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA AND JACK
dialogues.text: exchange an expression of victory. 271

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: recovers from all the excitement by draining his pocket f

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: This stuff has really lost its kick. He tosses the empty flask aside. 272

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy strides across the concourse. 273

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND LYDIA
dialogues.text: observe the Cowboy from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: There he is. The Cowboy. I've been tracking his movements for months. Jack looks nervous; he glances anxiously at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What has this got to do with Tuck?  Revised 11/8/85 79.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Good question.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Maybe everything. (beat) The Cowboy deals in stolen technology. He's a middleman. Why do you think he arrived today? Dollars to donuts he leads us right to that chip. The Cowboy gets on a pay phone.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I'd love to know who he's calling.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Maybe I can hear.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I mean it.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: He's fifty feet away.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Let me try... 274

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: makes the proper adjustments to heighten the sensitivity of Jack's hearing. 275

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: looks directly at the Cowboy and begins to hear, despite the echoing din of the crowded concourse.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He's leaving a message for somebody... (beat; listens) Victor Scrimshaw. (beat) Hey! That was the guy in the truck! Amazed, Lydia fumbles in her pockets for a pad and pencil

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (listening) He's staying at the Mark Hopkins Hotel. He wants Scrimshaw to pick him up at six in the morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 80.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: (taking notes) Six in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (listening) He says he never sleeps. The Cowboy hangs up and walks off. notebook. Lydia puts away her

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: (to Jack) You're amazing.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (smiling) You're pretty wonderful yourself. Lydia smiles awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Let's go. As they walk briskly off:

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Who is Victor Scrimshaw, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: He's very mysterious -- and very powerful. I can call the paper for his file when we get there.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Get where?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: The Mark Hopkins Hotel. 276

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy arrives by cab. Moments later, Jack and Lydia drive up in the Ferrari. They disappear into the hotel parking garage. 277

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack finds a parking space. Oddly enough, there are at least twenty other Ferraris parked nearby. Jack and Lydia get out from the car.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: This place looks like a Ferrari owner's convention!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 81.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Get the suitcase from the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Huh?...

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I'm checking in. It's less suspicious if I have a suitcase. Jack opens the trunk, discovers the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: How'd you know this was here?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Tuck always keeps a packed suitcase in the trunk -(suggestively) -- just in case he wakes up in a 'strange place.' 278

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: winces painfully.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (to himself) Didn't know she knew about that suitcase. 279

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy has just registered. A Bell Boy is taking him to his room. As they walk to the elevators, they pass a signboard that reads:

dialogues.speaker: FERRARI OWNERS OF AMERICA
dialogues.text: National Convention Main Ball Room 280

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowboy sits on the bed polishing a pair of dressy lizards Country & Western MUSIC plays LOUDLY from the radio. 281

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can hear the loud C & W music pounding through the w

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I tipped the desk clerk a twenty. He put us right next door to the Cowboy. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 82.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Listen for any sound of him leaving his room. I'll be in the bedroom calling my paper.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Okay. Jack watches Lydia depart into the bedroom; his eyes drinking in every inch of her. 282

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: also ogles Lydia on his monitor, SIGHING deeply to himsel

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Hey! Cut that out! What are you looking at? I thought you were a gentleman! 283

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Tuck; softly) C'mon, Tuck. Who can blame me? She's one in a million. (beat) What's the deal between you two, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (angrily) Never mind. 284

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrimshaw is on the phone and he's hopping mad.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Margaret! I'm meeting with the Cowboy tomorrow morning and I still don't have that other chip! 285

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Canker is sitting on the edge of the bed in a spaghetti-strap negligee, the phone pressed to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: That's not much time, I -INTERCUT BETWEEN CANKER AND SCRI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 83.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: -- We had him! He slipped right through our fingers! I'm thinking maybe your boy Igoe's not all he's cracked up to be, Margaret! Canker's eyes begin to blaze.

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: You're crazy! (beat) He's the most perfect creature on earth. Just then, Igoe enters the bedroom wearing a silk robe, carrying a bottle of wine and two glasses. Canker regards him with adoration.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: (from phone) Just find that idiot supermarket clerk -- and don't let the Cowboy out of your sight, either! Igoe takes the phone from Canker's hands and hangs it up. She turns and throws open his robe revealing a tattoo on his chest. 286

dialogues.speaker: TATTOO
dialogues.text: A large heart, filled with roses and a scroll with the name "Margaret" written across it. 287

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: gently runs her fingers over the tattoo, then looks up into Igoe's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: Come to Momma. He embraces her passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duane Flornoy is on the phone. He has punched up Victor Scrimshaw's file on his computer -- the monitor before hi displays Scrimshaw's picture and bio.

dialogues.speaker: FLORNOY
dialogues.text: (into phone) ... This is one mean dude, Lydia. I can't believe this guy: Legal council to reputed organized crime figures; administrator of four teamster pension funds; suspected of black market arms dealing... yet somehow he manages to keep his nose clean. 289

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia on the phone, taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: FLORNOY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat) They say he keeps Jimmy Hoffa's wristwatch in his desk drawer as a souvenir. 290

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuck casts a concerned glance at his air-supply gauge.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Jack, I've got about nine hours of air left in here. I think it's time we formulate a plan. 291

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is stealing a glance at Lydia through the partiallyc Great! 292

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A plan. Let's do it.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: seems troubled by Jack's sudden enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: You're awfully eager, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 85.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You bet. I'm into this now. I'm hooked on adventure. What's your plan? Tuck isn't sure he likes this new attitude of Jack's.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: Okay. The Cowboy will lead us to the chip, right?

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: So... you're going to be the Cowboy. 293

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: wears a frozen half-smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Sure. And when Scrimshaw's men come by to pick up the Cowboy, they're gonna get you and me instead.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah... but I don't look like the Cowboy.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Let me worry about that. Jack seems hesitant. Then he sees Lydia emerging from bedroom -- her usual vision of efficient loveliness. All right.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: You'll do what?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (to Lydia) I have a plan... 294

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cowboy is trying on a flamboyantly embroidered silk Western shirt in front of the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 86.

dialogues.speaker: COWBOY
dialogues.text: (singing along with the radio in a weird, thick accent) '... Mama, don't let your sons grow up to be cowboys...' He continues to sing as he puts on his generous supply of gold rings, chains and bracelets. 295

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lydia has just heard Jack's plan. She seems resistant.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I don't know, Jack. It's a good plan, but it seems dangerous. Victor Scrimshaw likes to play hardball.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (firmly) I'm not afraid.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Well... neither am I. I've never run from danger in my life.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then don't start now.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: I'm not going to... (beat) ... but are you sure you can pull this off?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (modestly clears his throat) Well... I do have two years of high school drama under my belt. As a matter of fact, I once understudied the Sky Masterson role in a production of Guys and Dolls.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Good. That's good, Jack. The thing to do now is stay close to the Cowboy. Wherever he goes tonight, that's where we're going.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We're not exactly dressed for a night on the town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Revised 11/8/85 87.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: (heading for the door) There's a dress shop in the lobby. (beat) You can dip into Tuck's suitcase. 296

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (to Jack; peevishly) Go ahead! Dip all you want. Nothing will fit you! 297

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack has just finished dressing into Tuck's clothes. A rumpled but sporty look. And everything fits. Lydia emerges from the bedroom in her new dress. Jack turns in her direction and has to gasp for breath.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You look... beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Jack. And you look... Her voice trails off. A wistful look comes into her expression and she gently runs her hand down Jack's lapel

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing. I was just reminded of a time when Tuck wore this jacket... 298

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: seems to melt as he views Lydia's melancholy expression.

dialogues.speaker: TUCK
dialogues.text: (as if he were talking directly to Lydia) It was the night we first met. You were writing that article about me. We had dinner and talked until three in the morning. I got drunk and fell down a manhole walking you home. 299

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND LYDIA
dialogues.text: The SOUND of a DOOR CLOSING breaks the mood.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A door... The Cowboy!

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA
dialogues.text: He's leaving. Lydia peeks out into the: 300

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: where the Cowboy is walking. He turns down another corrid passing a ROOM SERVICE WAITER, and heads for the elevator 301

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA HOLDS ON ROOM SERVICE WAITER

dialogues.text: Crowded. jammed. Smoke-filled. MUSIC BLASTING. Jack and Wendy are dancing. The dance floor As they dance:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY

dialogues.speaker: WENDY

I think you're the only person at the market I haven't slept with, and like -- you're the only one I'm even partially attracted to! Jack smiles painfully.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY

INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 100. A friendly-looking GOLDEN RETRIEVER is curled restfully on the floor near its food dish. Scrimshaw rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNERSPACE - Rev. 12/3/85 100A. Jack and Lydia glance around the table at the decidedly unfriendly faces of the henchmen. They sit. Scrimshaw produces two cigars from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: (to Jack) Please join me. I believe these are the kind you like... Cuban. Jack takes the cigar and lights up apprehensively. is probably his first cigar. He draws in deeply. 337 This

dialogues.text: is choking on cigar smoke. Lydia slaps him on the back. Scrimshaw looks on. Finally Jack regains his composure. He puts the cigar to one side.

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: All right, then. So much for the pleasantries. Let's get down to business. (glances at Canker) Dr. Canker. Canker clears her throat.

dialogues.text: (to Jack) Miniaturization works on a dual-chip system. We have one chip in our possession at this moment. We will have the other one shortly. Scrimshaw anticipates an angry reaction from Jack -- but doesn't get one. Fine.

dialogues.text: I'll take what you've got. Canker and Scrimshaw exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: CANKER
dialogues.text: (to Jack) You do understand, the first chip only miniaturizes... both chips are required for re-enlargement.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Right. We'll whet their appetites with what we've got!

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Good point. (to Canker) Show him the chip. Canker takes a gold pill box from her pocket and places i on the table. Jack and Lydia conceal their excitement. Canker opens the pill box and holds up the chip with a pair of surgical tweezers. 339

dialogues.speaker: SCRIMSHAW
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Cowboy. When it comes to re-attaching severed limbs, Dr. Canker here has pioneered the field.

dialogues.text: Damnit! Every time this guy shows up my equipment goes haywire! What's he got -- a pacemaker?! He loses radio and video contact. Lights flash on and off

dialogues.text: as his face begins to stretch and bulge! are totally out of control. The hormones His skull begins to enlarge. His neck thickens. His nose turns into an animal's snout and pushes forward from his Horrible SNAPPING, STRETCHING, CRACKING sounds are heard. Jack MOANS painfully. 346

Igoe throws his arms around Jack and locks him in a visel Scrimshaw pushes the Golden Retriever away from its dish Get outta there!! -- and begins to dig around in the gooey Kal-Kan for the 348

dialogues.text: Jack and Lydia are locked in the cellar. cally looks for a way out. Jack franti-
